results.title: Sawyer's View Master Viewing Reel - Hansel and Gretel
results.material_description: View Master viewing reel in paper envelope
results.brief_description:
View Master Viewing Reels from Sawyer’s, Inc.
FT-2 Hansel and gretel.
Originally Part 7 of P179116, individual record made for location tracking/ XOS purposes while on display (BUT it is on display in MI-08-C01 with the other reels from P179116? fmm 1/4/21)

results.title: Commodore C2N Datasette
results.brief_description: The Commodore 1530 (C2N) Datasette, later also Datassette (a portmanteau of data and cassette), is Commodore’s dedicated magnetic tape data storage device. Using compact cassettes as the storage medium, it provides inexpensive storage to Commodore’s 8-bit home/personal computers, notably the PET, VIC-20, and C64.

results.title: Ohnar 16MM Editor Viewer
results.brief_description: Film viewing and editing devices like the Ohnar provided amatuer filmmakers the ability to precisely edit their own home movies with relative ease. Popular among avid consumer-level filmmakers for their size, this 16mm film equipment allows hand cranking and has a convenient frame counting dial. The reel arms can be swivelled out and locked in place for use, and folded away for compact storage.

group_siblings.title: 16mm projector
group_siblings.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).

results.title: 16mm Film
results.brief_description: Most of the films in our collection are held on 16mm film, which was introduced in the 1920s as a cheaper alternative to the 35mm format and was widely adopted by amateur filmmakers. Because of its accessibility and popularity, it’s no surprise that we receive so many donations from the community, which along with the film itself, also comprises editing equipment and cameras. The Hanimex Eiki 16mm film projector displayed in this cabinet is typical of the kinds used in schools up until the 1980s, where films were screened in assembly halls to supplement standard learning in classrooms.

results.title: National Ranger 505 Transistor TV
results.creator_credit: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.description:
National Ranger 505 Transistor TV is a portable TV with handle, small screen and folding antennae. The television was completely portable - it could be powered with either mains power or batteries, allowing the user to kick back and take the TV to the beach, campground or backyard.

National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: Macintosh Classic
results.brief_description: If you took a computer class in Australia during the early 1990s, chances are you used one of these boxy personal computers. The Macintosh Classic was released in October 1990 and was the first Macintosh computer to sell for less than $1,000 US dollars, making it one of the most affordable computers on the market at the time. It was really just a cheaper version of the Macintosh SE without as many features, which had been released in 1987, and the Macintosh Classic was seen by some as an attempt to squeeze a few more years out of the earlier model. Part of its reduced cost was due to being made in Singapore, instead of America like previous Macintosh computers. Still, the price and stable operating system made it popular in schools, at home and for small business.

Part of its reduced cost was due to being made in Singapore, instead of America like previous Macintosh computers. Part of its reduced cost was due to being made in Singapore, instead of America like previous Macintosh computers. results.title: Pocket Cinema Camera 6K
results.credit_line: Courtesy Blackmagic Design, Major Partner of ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Pocket Cinema Camera 6K is the world’s lightest and most portable 6K digital film camera, designed specifically for independant filmmakers, TV and web broadcasters.

It offers Hollywood image quality and professional features in an affordable, ultra-portable and familiar DSLR format.

results.title: Pocket Cinema Camera 6K Partial Assembly
results.credit_line: Courtesy Blackmagic Design, Major Partner of ACMI
results.brief_description:
This partially assembled Pocket Cinema Camera displays some of the design detail required to achieve accurate, highly toleranced fitment of parts.
Internal components have been miniaturised to ensure the camera is compact enough for hand-held use, but capable of delivering cinematic film quality.
